Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Lauren Wheeler of the University of Maine to conduct a research project in Geosciences during the summer of 2013 at GNS Science in Lower Hutt, Wellington, New Zealand. The project title is "Modeling the Effects of Glaciation from the Last Glacial Maximum to Present on Mountain Building in the Central South Island of New Zealand." The host scientist is Dr. Phaedra Upton.

This project is examining the effects of glacial mass loading and unloading on the tectonics of New Zealand's central South Island using three-dimensional numerical modeling. The South Island is a highly-studied region, and the tectonics and glacial-interglacial periods are well constrained by both field observations and numerical models. These models give us the opportunity to develop a sense of how glaciation affects mountain building (topography and changes in strain) from the Last Glacial Maximum to present. Work of this kind is ongoing for southeast Alaska. The size of the glacial load on the South Island is comparable to those in Alaska. New Zealand and southeast Alaska are both tectonically active regions and comparing the two will develop a sense of how glaciation affects mountain building in multiple mountain ranges. Due to the spatial variation in both New Zealand and southeast Alaska, it is not sufficient to model these systems using a single two-dimensional cross section (as is often done) through the mountain range to represent the mechanics. This is especially inaccurate in a region where the mechanics are influenced by glaciation as glaciers vary in their spatial extent and thickness. Modeling the influence of glaciation on tectonics in three-dimensions is not only a new addition to the scientific literature and community but more accurately represents the region.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Furthermore, the University of Maine School of Earth and Climate Sciences is involved in synergistic activities with the local communities. This experience provides the opportunity to conduct an outreach program with local middle and high schools. The School of Earth and Climate Sciences often incorporates research projects into undergraduate course modules. The results and the research that stems from this project may be used as course modules in the Geophysics and Global Tectonics courses taught at the University of Maine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to examine the effects of glacial mass loading and unloading on the central South Island in New Zealand in three-dimensions (3D). The methods we developed for New Zealand were later applied to southeast Alaska, another tectonically active region with high deformation rates. Due to the spatial variation in both New Zealand and southeast Alaska, it is not sufficient to model these systems using a single two-dimensional (2D) cross section (as is often done) through the mountain range to represent the mechanics. This is especially inaccurate in a region where the mechanics are influenced by glaciation since glaciers vary in their spatial extent and thickness. Modeling the influence of glaciation on tectonics in 3D is not only a new addition to the scientific community but more accurately represents these regions.

We selected the central South Island of New Zealand because the tectonics are well studied and have been previously modeled.  The glacial-interglacial periods in New Zealand are well constrained by both field observations and numerical models as well. In both regions we included the modern topography at the surface of the model. The model was driven using the incoming large scale plate vectors for New Zealand (figure 1) and southeast Alaska (figure 2). The tectonic model was run until modern strain conditions were established for each region. After setting up the strain conditions we applied and removed the glacial load. The load used was calculated for the Last Glacial Maximum (~20,000 years ago) for each region (figure 3, figure 4). The loading was applied for the duration of the maximum LGM extent and then removed incrementally at the approximate rate of deglaciation.

Our results show that at both the valley glacier scale and ice sheet scale that the pattern of strain changes with glacial loading and unloading. Simulations were run for models that included weak zones along the major faults (faulted model) and no weak zones along the major faults (unfaulted model). For Alaska this includes the Transition and Fairweather faults and in New Zealand this includes the Alpine and Ostler faults. Results from the faulted models matches observations best for both regions. The results show higher strain along the faulted boundaries because less stress is required to overcome the strength along that boundary.

In Alaska these results are comparable with other models and observations. After glacial unloading in the Alaska model there is a steep gradient in the north-south strain (or YZI) in the Yakutat Bay region. This corresponds well with the epicenters of the 1899 earthquakes in Yakutat Bay, a combined tectonic and glacial isostatic response to Little Ice Age unloading. These models capture a response to a much larger unloading event, the LGM, at a low frequency and long wavelength and indicate that the response to glacial loading and unloading can still be detected at low frequencies and longer wavelengths. Results from the New Zealand models demonstrate that smaller valley glaciers can influence the local tectonics. In a faulted region, this could result in seismic release(s) along those faults. At present the historic seismic record is insufficient to compare with our results and we can’t constrain the New Zealand results with observations.
